message:
Yes, use ObservableCollection<t>.

NotifyTaskCompletion is really just an INotifyPropertyChanged wrapper for Task<t>. If that T changes, then it needs to support INotifyPropertyChanged or INotifyCollectionChanged itself.

So, if the collection changes after it has been retrieved, the proper type is NotifyTaskCompletion<observablecollection<t>>.

I'd like to answer my own question, but I'd very much welcome other answers: I'd use ObservableCollection<t> for properties that represents collection.

I guess I was trying to over-complicate by hooking up to the property changed events in the AsyncCommand and NotifyTaskCompletion. If I have an async method, let's say Refresh, which needs to run in the VM constructor then I could use NotifyTaskCompletion - if I also want to run the same method via a button cick then I can use AsyncCommand. However, these are different objects which require separate bindings in the XAML. What would be the correct way to achieve this functionality - e.g. could I create an AsyncCommand and call the Execute method in the VM constructor.
AsyncCommands, like any other kind of MVVM ICommand, do not support return values. At that level, you need to assign the results to a ViewModel property before the command completes.

Excellent articles but I have a question. My MVVM WPF application has a ViewModel which uses your AsyncCommand to fetch data from a database asynchronously on a button click. How can I pass the results of the AsyncCommand to a child viewmodel if the command completes successfully?

I think I see what you're trying to do. One pattern I've used often is to have a (regular synchronous) command start a NotifyTaskCompletion operation. So *starting* the operation isn't asynchronous. Is that what you're looking for?
Is there a fix somewhere? - I don't see any comments on the MSDN article.
Yes, there's a bug in the code that was posted with the MSDN article: if the operation completes synchronously, TaskCompleted will be null.

I was looking for a way in which I could use the same asynchronous method which loads data from an external source when the View first loads (i.e in the VM constructor) and via a Refresh button. NotifyTaskCompletion fits the first case and AsyncCommand the second. At the moment I use the latter and just call the Execute method of the command in the constructor. Probably not the best but it seems to work. I am using the AsyncEx version of NotifyTaskCompletion and had to make minor modifications to your AsyncCommand in the articles. There was a fix in the comments, before the Great Comment Purge of '15. I'm working with them to update the code download.
Asynchronous throttling is generally done using SemaphoreSlim. Then within the GetImageUrl method, do a WaitAsync to acquire the semaphore and when you're done, a Release to release it.

Wouldn't the code below achieve the same result without incurring the trouble of creating async methods in the ViewModel?

<label content="{Binding UrlByteCount, IsAsync=True, FallbackValue='Loading....'}"/>

It's not exactly the same. IsAsync is only available on WPF, whereas the techniques in my articles can be used with any MVVM framework.

Also, IsAsync will always execute the code on a background thread, so it would only work for thread-agnostic code.

I realize it's not exactly the same and the purpose of the MSDN articles are to highlight usage of TPL.   
The async behavior illustrated in the article is essentially a UI/Presentation Layer concern. I can't think of another reason to decorate your ViewModel with async methods other than providing a "responsive ui". This design decision will have a profound impact on how your unit tests are written/structured - not to mention the case where you might want to re-use the same ViewModel but perhaps without a UI, where we're not concerned at all that it takes a few extra seconds but we're concerned with performance and would like to minimize context switches etc.

I guess the point that I'm trying to make is this: If the objective is to make your UI responsive, we should handle that concern in the layer that is responsible for it. Our first line of thought should be not to think of writing async code in the ViewModel (which brings all sorts of other concerns with it - as much as TPL generally making it much easier to deal with) but to look at the facilities available to use in the stack we've chosen for our implementation. For this particular example, using WPF Binding with the IsAsync set to true gives us the responsive UI we're seeking all-the-while handling all details of the marshaling back and forth for us and not allowing that UI concern to creep deeper into our design.

There are a multitude of valid reasons to write async code, but if we're using WPF Binding, keeping a responsive UI is not one of them.

Is there any concrete sample of handling INotifyCollectionChanged by using NotifyTaskCompletion?
Thanks!

NotifyTask only updates properties as a whole. If you want to do an async operation that gradually adds items to a collection, I would recommend using something more like Progress<t> or an explicit callback.

A bit late to comment but i hope someone will reply.

The problem I'm facing is error handling.

In the example, it is easy to bind to the AsyncCommand.Execution to access the NotifyTaskCompletion object. Databinding will automatically find it and detect changes using INotifydPropertyChanged even though Execution is not exposed on the IAsyncCommand interface, and that a new NotifyTaskCompletion instance is created for each execution.

What if I wanted to execute the command manually in the view model, handle any errors on task completion and display an error dialog popup? (I want to reuse the command because the ui is binding to IsNotCompleted)  
I have to cast the IAsyncCommand to AsyncCommand, register and unregister to AsyncCommand.Execution and then Execution.PropertyChanged.

Is there a better way to do this?

For error handling, I recommend inserting a try/catch in the delegate passed to AsyncCommand.

But if you want to do it using Execution, then you can change the type of your command property from IAsyncCommand to AsyncCommand.
if i try catch inside of a task, then i have to use the dispatcher to display error dialog on ui thread
